awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Elements: Software: Accelerating Discovery of the First Stars through a Robust Software Testing Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
The birth of the first stars and galaxies 13 billions years ago -- our "Cosmic Dawn" -- is one of the last unobserved periods in the history of the Universe. Scientists are working to observe the 21 cm radio light emitted by the primeval neutral hydrogen fog as the first stars formed.  These observations are considered one of the grand challenges of modern astrophysics. This project will provide critical software infrastructure for the field of 21 cm cosmology, enabling rapid vetting of the new analyses and techniques developed for these observations and increasing their robustness, rigor, and reproducibility. Under this project The investigators will train students in the best practices for software and code development, preparing them to develop robust, reproducible software for their own research, contribute to large open source projects, and develop software in a professional setting.

One of the biggest challenges for the detection of the Epoch of Reionization is the presence of bright astrophysical foregrounds that obscures the signal of interest, requiring extraordinarily precise modeling and calibration of the radio telescopes performing these observations. The 21 cm cosmology community is rapidly developing new techniques for instrument calibration, foreground removal, and analysis, but thorough testing and integration into existing data analysis pipelines has been slow. This project will provide a software infrastructure that can enable rigorous, seamless testing of novel algorithmic developments within a unified framework. This infrastructure will ensure a level of reliability and reproducibility not possible with current tools and accelerate the speed at which developments become integrated into production level code, providing an invaluable foundation for bringing our field into the next decade and for leveraging the current NSF investments in these experiments.

This project is supported by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering and the Division of Astronomical Sciences in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the last outstanding goals of modern cosmology is to directly observe our "Cosmic Dawn", when the first stars in the universe lit up and burned away the primeval neutral hydrogen fog. These first stars and galaxies are extremely hard to observe, both because they are very distant and because the expansion of space has redshifted the light they do emit to wavelengths that are difficult to observe on Earth. One of the most promising avenues for studying these early stars and galaxies is by observing their effect on the neutral hydrogen gas that surrounds them using the redshifted 21cm line emission from the primordial hydrogen. Making statistical measurements of this emission, the 21cm power spectrum, is technically very challenging both because the signal is very faint and because the radio emission from our own galaxy and the hundreds of thousands of intervening radio galaxies is 4-5 orders-of-magnitude brighter than the cosmological signal. Isolating the 21cm cosmological signal in practice requires unprecedented calibration precision, control of instrumental systematics, and subtraction of bright foreground contamination.


Because the calibration precision, foreground subtraction accuracy, and spectral-spatial dynamic range needed for 21 cm cosmology are all orders-of-magnitude more precise than traditional radio astronomy, the four main data analysis teams pursuing this signal around the world have had to write their own software analysis pipelines. As deeper and deeper limits have been achieved, cross-validation and testing of the analysis techniques has become the key tool in identifying subtle instrument and analysis systematics and in validating the results. This proposal?s goal was to develop a software infrastructure to enable rigorous, seamless testing of 21 cm cosmology analysis pipelines.


This project built upon our prior experience developing the `pyuvdata` package that provides a python object with all the information needed for radio interferometry data, and read and write routines to all the common (and some uncommon) radio astronomy file formats. Key to pyuvdata's success was our active and deep community involvement and our adherence to best practices in open source software development.


The outcomes of this grant were the development of three python based objects providing generic interfaces for the major software components of a 21 cm cosmology radio astronomy project. Specifically, these three objects are: (1) A generic representation of calibration solutions, i.e., the complex response of the radio telescope (generally on an antenna-by-antenna basis) as a function of frequency, polarization, and time; (2) A generic representation of the instruments used in 21 cm cosmology experiments, with an emphasis on the primary beam, i.e., the complex spatial response of an individual antenna per-polarization; and (3) A generic representation of the foreground models used to mitigate foreground contamination and, in many cases, to calibrate the instruments. The first and second objects (UVCal and UVBeam) were implemented within the existing `pyuvdata` package, while the third object (SkyModel) was implemented in a separate python package, `pyradiosky`. These objects enable seamless modularization of existing 21 cm cosmology analysis pipelines, allowing for rapid testing and vetting of specific changes in the analyses.


The pyuvdata user community has grown significantly over the course of this grant and our objects are now being used with data from radio telescopes that are unrelated to 21cm cosmology, showing the broad usefulness of the software to the entire radio astronomy community.
